thread.title: Oil price drop drives $337m of write-downs at Origin Energy
thread.title_full: Oil price drop drives $337m of write-downs at Origin Energy | afr.com

author: Angela Macdonald-Smith
title: Oil price drop drives $337m of write-downs at Origin Energy
text:
Origin Energy's APLNG plant in Gladstone is one of three LNG plants being built side-by-side on Curtis Island. by Angela Macdonald-Smith Origin Energy will take a further $337 million of write-downs on its oil and gas business due to the slump in prices and cuts to reserves, but its $24.7 billion Australia Pacific liquefied natural gas project in Queensland has escaped any hit.
The biggest impact will be on Origin's Cooper Basin petroleum business in central Australia, which will be written down by $180 million after tax, Origin advised on Wednesday.
The Bass Basin business will be written down by $122 million, and the Otway Basin business by $35 million.
Origin blamed the impairments, to be taken in the full-year results on August 20, on recent revisions to its oil and gas reserves, as well as revised project development plans and lower crude prices. It has tested the value of its assets against forward prices for Brent crude oil, then assuming $US80 a barrel prices from the 2020 financial year.
It had already advised of a $53 million write-down on its New Zealand onshore petroleum business at the half-year stage.
Some analysts have pointed to APLNG as a potential risk for write-downs, especially after last year's move by BG Group to cut the carrying value of its new LNG project in Queensland, partly on lower long-term assumptions for sales prices after last year's rout in oil prices.
But Origin specifically said APLNG, which is due to begin production in the December quarter slightly behind its original mid-2015 target, was not affected.
"There is no impairment related to Australia Pacific LNG, the economics of Origin's investment in Australia Pacific LNG remain robust," it said in the statement.
